Keywords Reservoir Computing Echo State Networks Intrinsic Plasticity Deep Neural Encoders Feature dimensionality reduction Affective computing 1 Introduction Affective Computing (AC) is a research field that aims to automatically detect and quantify human emotions. Major techniques for affect detection are voice or facial expressions, text, body posture or language [1, 2]. Affective Neuroscience emerged recently as a new AC approach that attempts to find the neural correlated between human emotions and registered brain activity. Electroencephalography (EEG) is one of the most exploited brain imaging techniques due to its accessibility in several research labs and clinical environments. Comprehensive review of EEG-based emotion recognition systems is provided in [3]. It is difficult to compare the results, because of factors such as data acquisition scenarios, number of participants, emotion models, type of stimulus and extracted features, temporal windows, etc. However, most of the solutions build a recognition model for each participant (subject dependent model) [4–7]. Building models that cover multiple subjects (i.e. subject independent models) is a challenging problem due to the intrinsic variability of the registered brain activity among different participants [8]. For example in [3] based on the Power Spectral Density (PSD) in different frequency bands of the EEG signal and Support Vector Machine (SVM) classifier, happy/unhappy emotions are discriminated with accuracy of 75.62% for the subject dependent setting and only 62.12% for the generalized subject independent setting. In [9], emotion clustering with 84% inter-subjects accuracy is presented based on similarities between phase portraits constructed from the time-response of a Duffing oscillator. The results are obtained with simulated data with low signal to noise ratio (<10dB). In [10] exhaustive feature reduction improves the inter-subject accuracy up to 80%. More challenging problem of four emotions (pleasure, joy, sadness, anger) is considered in [11] with 82% inter-subject accuracy. The emotion recognition systems across multiple subjects have to come up with the problem of choosing the most relevant features for all participants and the usually high dimensional feature space. Working on this problem in [12] we proposed the Echo State Network (ESN) as a mechanism for low dimensional feature space projection in the EEG-based affective computing. The ESNs are dynamical structures designed to facilitate learning in Recurrent Neural Networks (RNN), normally applied for time series modeling. Using ESNs for static data classification or clustering gained less attention. In [13] we proposed a novel approach to extract the equilibrium reservoir states that maximize the model discrimination capacity after Intrinsic Plasticity (IP) adaptation of the reservoir states. Based on IP-trained ESN and after search for the optimal combination of equilibrium reservoir states we obtained subject independent classification models of human emotion valence that outperformed the above referenced studies. The experience gained suggested that a reliable inter-subject neural decoding is feasible only if the features are carefully reduced to the most discriminative ones. The goal of the present work is twofold. First, we explore the limits of the ESNs low dimensional representations and define the optimal reservoir states combination that can serve as the most discriminative features particularly in inter-subject affective computing setting. Secondly, we make a broad comparison between the IP-trained ESNs with classical ESNs (with randomly generated reservoir) and the state of the art Deep Neural Autoencoders (DNA). DNAs are based on the concept of Deep Neural Networks (DNN) [14] where the subsequent hidden layers, called auto-encoders, map the input data into representation features with different level of abstraction. We argue that the extraction of optimal low dimensional combinations of IP-trained reservoir equilibrium states is more promising mechanism than the auto-encoders for data representation and feature dimensionality reduction in the framework of the EEG-based affective computing. The paper is organized as follows. In Section 2 the IP-adaptation in Reservoir Computing (RC) is outlined and our approach for RC-based feature extraction is presented. In Section 3 the experimental scenario and the EEG data acquisition are described. In Section 4 a clustering approach for the ESN-based emotion valence discrimination from EEG signals is proposed, and in Section 5 the same problem is solved as a classification task. IP-tuned ESN is compared with Deep Neural Encoders in Section 6. Discussion of the results and conclusions are summarized in Section 7. 2 Reservoir adaptation with Intrinsic Plasticity 2.1 Reservoir Computing Recurrent Neural Networks (RNN) represent a large class of computational models particularly suitable for nonlinear time series processing. However, despite their successful application in academic and practical problems, the RNN training is only feasible for relatively small networks. A promising approach to overcome the RNN shortcomings was proposed independently by Wolfgang Maass under the name Liquid State Machines [15] and by Herbert Yaeger under the name of Echo State Networks [16]. This approach is often referred to as Reservoir Computing (RC), [17]. In this work the Echo State Network (ESN) formalism of RC is used. The basic structure of the ESN, presented on Fig. 1, consists of one hidden layer, called dynamic reservoir, of randomly connected sigmoid neurons, usually tanh nonlinear functions f res (1) r ( k ) = f r e s ( W i n i n ( k ) + W r e s r ( k − 1 ) ) and a linear function f out at the output (readout): (2) o u t ( k ) = f o u t ( W o u t [ i n ( k ) r ( k ) ] ) Here k denotes discrete time instant, in(k) is the vector of ESN inputs with dimension n in , r(k) is the vector of reservoir neurons states with dimension n r and out(k) is the vector of ESN outputs with dimension n out . W in and W res are randomly generated matrices of the input and the reservoir weights that remain unchanged during network training. Only the output weights (matrix W out ) are trained. In some applications direct input-output connection is not supposed. In contrast to the classical RNN where the reservoir and the readout weights are trained in the same way, the ESN treats them differently. The purpose of the reservoir is to expand the input history into a rich enough reservoir state space r(k) while the readout combines the neuron signals r(k) into the desired output signal out target (k). The weights of the reservoir neurons are randomly generated from a uniform distribution symmetric around zero. An important ESN property is that the reservoir should possess the so called echo state property. This means that the effect of the current state r(k) and the current input in(k) on a future state r(k+n) should decrease as time passes ( n → ∞ ). There have been various attempts to define rules that guarantee the echo state property and optimize the reservoir. Many of them are based on experience, heuristics or exhaustive search over the parameter space. A promising biologically motivated mechanism called intrinsic plasticity (IP) has recently attracted a wide attention in the reservoir computing community [18]. 2.2 Intrinsic Plasticity The IP adaptation rule aims at maximization of information transmission trough the ESN that is equivalent to its output entropy maximization. Motivation of this approach is related to known biological mechanisms that change neural excitability according to the distribution of the input stimuli. In [19] a gradient method for adjusting the biases is proposed and an additional gain term to achieve the desired distribution of outputs by minimizing the Kullback-Leibler divergence: (3) D K L ( p ( r ) , p d ( r ) ) = ∫ p ( r ) log ( p ( r ) p d ( r ) ) d r D KL measures the difference between the actual p(r) and the desired p d (r) probability distribution of the reservoir states r. In [18] the IP formalism for hyperbolic tangent neuron transfer functions and Gaussian output distribution is derived (4) p d ( r ) = 1 σ 2 π exp ( − ( r − μ ) 2 2 σ 2 ) Now, the expression (3) can be rearranged as follows: (5) D K L ( p ( r ) , p d ( r ) ) = − H ( r ) + 1 2 σ 2 E ( ( r − μ ) 2 ) + log 1 σ 2 π , where H denotes entropy. The last term in (5) is constant and the second term determines the deviation of the reservoir state r from the desired mean value. The minimization of (5) is a compromise between the entropy maximization and the minimization of the distance between μ and r. In order to achieve this effect two additional reservoir parameters – the gain a and the bias b (both vectors with size n r ) - are introduced as follows: (6) r ( k ) = f r e s ( d i a g ( a ) W i n i n ( k ) + d i a g ( a ) W r e s r ( k − 1 ) + b ) The IP adaptation adjusts a and b using iterative gradient descent: a i t = a i t − 1 + Δ a b i t = b i t − 1 + Δ b where it denotes iteration number and the gradients Δ a and Δ b are derivatives of Kullback-Leibler divergence with respect to vectors a and b. In the case of hyperbolic tangent reservoir neurons ( f res =tanh) the gradients are: Δ b = − η ( − μ σ 2 + r σ 2 ( 2 σ 2 + 1 − r 2 + μ r ) ) Δ a = η a + Δ b n e t i n p u t n e t i n p u t = W i n i n + W r e s r Here η is the learning rate. The IP adaptation tends to concentrate the reservoir outputs according to the parameters of the targeted Gaussian distribution p d (r). The equilibrium state of the reservoir r e for a constant input in c can be determined as: (7) r e = tanh ( d i a g ( a ) W i n i n c + d i a g ( a ) W r e s r e + b ) In case b=0 and in c =0, the equilibrium will be at the origin of the reservoir state space coordinate system. Otherwise it will be moved depending on the values of input in c and bias b vectors. Since the input weight matrix remains constant, the first term in the brackets will be also constant for a constant inputs in c . Thus we can consider it together with the bias term as a common bias for a given input vector: (8) r e = tanh ( d i a g ( a ) W r e s r e + b i n c ) , b i n c = d i a g ( a ) W i n i n c + b The reservoir equilibrium states vary randomly within the hyperbolic tangent interval [−1+1]. After the IP adaptation rule they will be squeezed into the interval determined by the variance σ . The convergence of the reservoir states to the expected distributions is proven in [18]. Typical values for the key parameters of the algorithm suggested in [18] are: zero mean, variance=0.1, learning rate η=0.0005, a=1 and b=0 as initial values. The IP training stops when no significant changes of the equilibrium states are observed. In [20] we have shown that in fact IP adaptation rule achieves balance between maximization of entropy at the ESN reservoir output and its concentration around the pre-specified mean value increasing at the same time reservoir stability. 2.3 ESN reservoir for extraction of low dimensional features In [21] we have observed that the reservoir equilibrium states are concentrated in several regions and they depend on the input vectors. If the input vectors are close in the input space, they will result in close equilibrium points in the reservoir state. Let consider the following experiment: Well separated data clusters were generated in 3D unit cube space (see Fig. 2) and the data was input into an ESN reservoir. In Fig. 3 are depicted some of the 2D combinations of reservoir neuron outputs scaled within interval [−1, +1] before and after the IP-training. It is easy to see that the representation of the input data into 2D reservoir projections before the IP training does not reflect well the cluster separation compared to the reservoir state distribution after the IP training. Note also that not all 2D neurons output combinations are equally successful in detecting the clusters. Each couple of neurons can be considered as different “point of view projection” of multidimensional input space into the two dimensional neurons equilibriums. Thus, the question is how to find the best projections that represent the data structure? The IP training forces the reservoir outputs to pre-specified Gaussian distributions. See for example in Fig. 4 (top), the probability density distributions of equilibrium states of ten neurons from the initial ESN reservoir and achieved after IP tuning new distributions of neurons equilibriums at Fig. 4 (bottom). As seen, the neuron output distribution is a combination of several Gaussian distributions. Red triangles on the figure mark the maxima of the local Gaussian distribution curves. Neurons 1 and 7 have the highest number of local maxima and the finest data separation as seen in Fig. 4 (bottom). This observation formulated the idea of using the ESN reservoir for extraction of low dimensional features. The main steps of the algorithm we proposed in [13] to extract the equilibrium reservoir states that maximize the discrimination capacity after IP training are summarized below. Step 1: Define the ESN structure and generate the initial ESN state. The ESN input dimension is equal to the number of the original features. Choose the number of reservoir neurons and generate random neuron weights. Substitute the ESN readout by a clustering or classification technique. Step 2: Iterative IP adaptation of the ESN reservoir states according to Eqs.(4–8) until equilibrium states r e , are reached. Step 3: Generate low dimensional projections of the equilibrium states (combinations of reservoir neurons) - an iterative procedure with the following sub-steps: a) Create all possible 2D combinations of the equilibrium states of the reservoir neurons, obtained after IP training. Use these 2D combinations as inputs for classification/clustering models; rank the models based on some performance measure (for example in this work we use the accuracy on test data). b) Select C best ranked models. Use their corresponding 2D feature vectors to generate 3D combinations adding one by one the rest of reservoir neurons equilibrium states. Use these 3D combinations as inputs for classification/clustering models and rank them. c) Select again C best ranked combinations and as in the previous step use them to create 4D feature vectors; fit and rank classification/clustering models. d) Repeat Step 3 generating higher dimensional feature vectors until no significant improvement in the discrimination accuracy is observed. Step 3 is computationally the most expensive step. The number of all combinations of neurons is (n r -! /(n r —k+1)! * k), where n r is the reservoir size, k is the number of neurons in the combination. In order to reduce the computational complexity, the projections after step 3a (higher than 2D projections) are constructed from a subset of C best ranked 2D projections (for step 3b), C best ranked 3D projections (for step 3c), etc. In the experiments, in Sections 4 and 5, C is set up to 20. 3 EEG data acquisition and initial feature set extraction The human emotion granularity can be schematically represented in two dimensions: i) valence, varying from negative to positive, and ii) arousal (emotion intensity), varying from low to high. The combination of these affective dimensions forms four emotional categories, which incorporate several discrete human emotions, such as joy, pleasure, excitement, melancholy, anger, fear, disgust, etc. Thus, any emotion-related bio-signal can be differentiated according to its valence or arousal dimension [22]. We aim to discriminate the positive and negative emotion valence, based on EEG data generated in response to external stimuli, aka Event Related Potentials (ERP). The ERPs were recorded while 26 female volunteers were viewing pictures selected from the International Affective Picture System (IAPS) repository. A total of 24 high arousal (IAPS rating>6) images with positive (M=7.29+/−0.65) and negative (M=1.47+/−0.24) valence were selected. For each image, signals from 21 EEG channels were sampled at 1kHz and stored. The raw EEG signals were first filtered (between 0.1 and 30Hz.), eye-movement corrected, baseline compensated and segmented into epochs using NeuroScan software. The ensemble average for each condition (positive/negative valence) was also computed and filtered with passband [0.5–15] Hz. See [13] for more details on data description. Twelve temporal features were stored corresponding to the amplitudes of the first three local minimums (Amin1, Amin2, Amin3), the first three local maximums (Amax1, Amax2, Amax3), and their associated latencies (Lmin1, Lmin2, Lmin3, Lmax1, Lmax2, Lmax3). Recent studies report evidence that the above temporal features correlate well with stimulus loaded with intensive emotions [23]. Thus, the initial feature set is a matrix X with dimension of 252 columns (21 channels x12 features) and 52 lines (the ensemble averaged positive and negative labeled trials of 26 subjects). In the experiments the normalized feature matrix was used, i.e. (X-mean(X))/std(X). 4 Clustering with ESN –experimental results 4.1 Low dimensional combinations of equilibrium states In this section the algorithm described in Section 2.3 is implemented to discriminate the positive and negative emotion valence across multiple subjects. The ESN input is provided with the normalized original features (252) described in Section 3. The ESN reservoir dimension varies between 10 and 500 neurons. The readout of the IP-adapted ESN is substituted by k-means ( Fig. 5) and fuzzy C-means (FCM, Fig. 6) clustering algorithms. The clustering algorithms are provided with the following features: i) All equilibrium states of the reservoir (ESN all). ESN with 10, 30, 50, 100, 150, 300 and 500 neurons are tested. ii) 2D, 3D, 4D, 5D, 6D and 7D combinations of equilibrium states. On Fig. 5 and Fig. 6 are presented only the results with those combinations that maximize the clustering accuracy; iii) Direct clustering. In this case the ESN is switched of and the clustering algorithms are provided with the original normalized feature matrix (252 features). The numerical values related with Fig. 5 and Fig. 6 are summarized in Table 1 and Table 2, respectively. The IP procedure converges after 5–10 iterations. Note that while the 2D combinations of equilibrium states (step 3a of the algorithm described in Section 2.3) range over all reservoir neurons, the subsequent nD combinations (steps 3b, 3c, 3d) are obtained from the best C=20 combinations of reservoir states kept at the previous step. Clustering based on the best low dimensional nD (n=2,3,4,5,6,7) combinations of equilibrium states clearly outperforms clustering using all reservoir equilibrium states (ESN all) or direct clustering of the original feature matrix. For large range of the reservoir dimension (10−500), direct clustering and ESN all scenarios do not provide better discrimination than a random chance. Higher the reservoir size lower the accuracy for the ESN all scenario In contrast, nD (n=2,3,4,5,6,7) features extracted particularly from reservoirs with high number of neurons (150, 300 500) achieve significantly higher performance with close to 80% accuracy (for 2D projections) to more than 90% accuracy (for 6D and 7D projections). This is a very promising result in the context of such challenging by its nature inter-subject clustering task. As it can be expected above a certain limit for n (n=7 in this case) there is no further improvement in the clustering performance. 4.2 IP-adapted ESN versus classical ESN with randomly generated reservoir states The benefits of using IP adaptation rule are demonstrated with this experiment. On Fig. 7 and Fig. 8 are depicted the discrimination accuracy of k-means and FCM clustering for varying ESN reservoir size (from 10 to 500 neurons) provided with the following features: i) All randomly generated reservoir states (ESN_ini_all) versus all equilibrium states after IP training ((ESN_ip_all); ii) 2D combinations of reservoir states without IP training (ESN_ini_2D) and after IP training ((ESN_ip_2D). iii) Direct clustering with the initial feature matrix (the same scenario as in 4.1.iii) The results show that we always get an improvement in performance after IP-adaptation of the reservoir. We also see that the effect of IP training is more expressive when 2D combinations of reservoir states with and without IP training are compared. The numerical values related with Fig. 7 and Fig. 8 are given in Table 3 and Table 4, respectively. 5 Classification with ESN –experimental results 5.1 Low dimensional combinations of equilibrium states Now we consider the same problem as in Section 4 formulated as a classification task. The ESN reservoir dimension varies again between 10 and 500 neurons. The readout of the IP-adapted ESN is substituted by a classification algorithm. The following standard classifiers are compared: Linear Discriminant Analysis (LDA), k-Nearest Neighbors (kNN), Naïve Bayes (NB), Support Vector Machines (SVM) and Decision Trees (DT). The classifiers are provided with the following features: i) All equilibrium states of reservoirs with 10, 30, 50, 100, 150, 300 and 500 neurons ( Fig. 9). ii) 2D ( Fig. 10), 3D ( Fig. 11), 4D ( Fig. 12), 5D ( Fig. 13) and 6D ( Fig. 14) combinations of equilibrium states. On the figures are presented only the results with those combinations that maximize the classification accuracy of each classifier. The numerical values related with the figures are given in Tables 5–8, respectively. Similarly to the clustering approach, the nD combinations (for n>2) are obtained from the best ranked twenty combinations of reservoir states kept at the previous step, as a way to control the computational complexity. At each training iteration, data belonging to one subject (26 subjects in total) is left aside and used for model testing (leave-one-subject-out cross validation). Thus, 26-fold cross validation is performed and only testing results are presented on the figures. The results show that increasing the reservoir dimension improves the classification accuracy up to a certain threshold of nD projections (n=6, Fig. 14). This tendency is related with the increasing number of equilibrium state combinations and therefore higher search resolution for discovering the best discriminative feature vectors. Above 6D combinations there was no further improvement in the correct classification. The very high testing accuracy (above 95%) achieved by most of the classifiers for 5D and 6D combinations outperform all previously published results in affective computing based on brain neural data. Similar to the clustering process, classification based on the best low dimensional nD (n=2,3,4,5,6) combinations of equilibrium states is superior compared to classification using all reservoir equilibrium states (Fig. 9). Classification with all equilibrium states as features is not much affected by the reservoir dimension variation (Fig. 9). However the classifiers may diverge significantly in performance which is overall low (between 45% and 75%). Finally, it is observed that solving the problem as a classification task is more plausible than the clustering approach. 6 Deep Neural Autoencoder model of emotion valence discrimination Neural networks with multiple hidden layers are useful for solving classification problems with complex nonlinear data. Each layer can learn features at a different level of abstraction. However, similar to the Recurrent Neural Networks (RNN), training neural networks with multiple hidden layers by back-propagation algorithm is difficult in practice. The learning time does not scale well, it is very slow in networks with multiple hidden layers, it can get stuck in poor local optima. Deep Neural Autoencoders (DNA) attempt to overcome these problems, following a similar concept to the IP-adapted ESN. The DNA hidden layers are first pre-trained individually in an unsupervised fashion using auto-encoders [14]. Both ESN and DNA map the data into a representative feature space and make the training feasible. In this section we build DNA models of emotion valence discrimination and compare them with the reservoir computing solution. The following procedure for DNA training is implemented: a) Training the first hidden layer (called auto-encoder) on the training data without using the labels. An auto-encoder is a neural network which attempts to replicate its input at its output. Thus, the size of its input will be the same as the size of its output. The auto-encoder is comprised of an encoder followed by a decoder. The encoder maps an input to a hidden representation and the decoder attempts to reverse this mapping to reconstruct the original input; b) The next hidden layers (autoencoders) are trained in a similar way. The main difference is that the features that are generated from the previous autoencoder are the training data for the next autoencoder. The size of each subsequent encoder is decreased, so that it learns a smaller representation of the input data. c) Unlike the autoencoders, the final (output) layer is trained in a supervised fashion using labels for the training data. We have used softmax function as a processing unit in this layer. d) Final retraining of the whole multilayer network is performed on the training data in a supervised fashion applying standard backpropagation. This step is referred as fine DNA tuning. We built DNA classification models with one, two and three auto-encoders ( Fig. 15). The size of the DNA input vector corresponds to the number of the original features (252). The size of the first encoder varies between 10 and 500 neurons. The results for single autoencoder DNAs with 10, 30, 50, 100,150, 300 and 500 neurons are visualized on Fig. 16. When the size of the encoder is less than the size of the input (i.e. encoders with 10, 30, 50, 100 and 150 neurons), the auto-encoder learns a compressed representation of the input. In the opposite case (i.e. encoders with 300 and 500 neurons) the auto-encoder projects the input data into a higher dimensional representation, similar to kernel-based data transformation. The results in Fig. 16 do not show benefits of expanding the input data compared to the compressed data representation. For DNAs with two and three auto-encoders we applied the rule for size reduction of each subsequent encoder. Thus, for example if the second encoder is L2=5, we build two layers DNNs (see Fig. 17) with varying first encoder L1={10,30,50, 100,150, 300) and if L2=150 then there is only one option for L1=300. Similarly, for three layers DNA (see Fig. 18), if the third encoder is L3=5, we built six DNAs with the following L1-L2 dimensions (50-15, 150-20, 300-50, 300-150, 500-100, 500-300) and if L3=150, again there is only one option for L1-L2=500-300. Following the decreasing layer size rule in Fig. 17 and Fig. 18 are depicted the testing classification accuracies for a number of DNA with 2 hidden layers (L1-L2) and DNA with three hidden layers (L1-L2-L3) with varying layer size. The best accuracy with test data (81%) was obtained both for two layers (300-50) and three layers (500-300-50) DNA. The DNA auto-encoder training and the subsequent hidden layer extraction with decreasing size is similar of the low dimensional projections (nD, n=1,2,3,…) of the ESN model. The results show however, that the IP-pretraining is more suitable mechanism than the DNA for data representation and feature dimensionality reduction in the framework of the EEG-based affective computing. For example the IP-trained ESN with maximum of 6D reservoir feature space extracted from 300 or 500 reservoir equilibrium neurons achieved around 90% clustering accuracy (Fig. 5, Fig. 6) and above 95% classification accuracy (Fig. 14) compared to the 81% of the most successful DNA models (Fig. 17, Fig. 18). 7 Conclusions We have shown that using reservoir computing pre-training is beneficial for selecting the most relevant discriminative features and reaching state-of-the-art performance for subject independent emotion valence recognition. This study confirmed the observation that the reservoir computing approach can be used not only for time series processing but also for high dimensional static data representation. We also presented experimental evidence that IP-trained ESN can boost performance compared to classical (without pre-training) ESN both in solving clustering and classification tasks. Finally we have demonstrated that IP-trained ESNs outperform pre-trained deep neural auto-encoders and can actually achieve above 95% testing accuracy. The cost for this significant improvement is the computational time required to test all feature vector combinations and extract the most discriminative ones. This problem is particularly relevant for big reservoirs. For example for a reservoir with 500 neurons, 124750 combinations of 2D equilibrium states need to be analyzed. Therefore, we proposed to tackle this problem by ranking the neuron combinations at each iteration and choosing only the best C combinations for the next iteration. The results in this paper can potentially contribute to the ongoing debate on data representation and training algorithms, especially whether DNN are more suited for large-scale machine learning problems. Therefore, applying the algorithm presented in Section 2 on ESNs in different context seems an attractive line of future research in order to obtain a solid comparison. doc_title: EEG dynamic source localization using constrained particle filtering
doc_abstract: © 2016 IEEE.We consider the dynamic EEG source localization problem with additional constraints on the expected value of the state. In dynamic EEG source localization, the brain sources, also called dipoles, are not stationary but vary over time. Moreover, given our specific EEG experiment, we expect the dipoles to be located within a certain area of the brain (here, the visual cortex). We formulate this constrained dynamic source localization problem as a constrained non-linear state-estimation problem. Particle filters (PFs) are nowadays the state-of-the-art in optimal non-linear and non-Gaussian state estimation. However, PFs cannot handle additional constraints on the state that cannot be incorporated within the system model. In this case, the additional constraint is on the mean of the state, which means that realizations of the state, also called particles within the PF framework, may or may not satisfy the constraint. However, the state must satisfy the constraint on average. This is indeed the case when tracking brain dipoles from EEG experiments that try to target a specific cortex of the brain. Such constraints on the mean of the state are hard to deal with because they reflect global constraints on the posterior density of the state. The popular solution of constraining every particle in the PF may lead either to a stronger condition or to a different (unrelated) condition; both of which result in incorrect estimation of the state. We propose the Iterative Mean Density Truncation (IMeDeT) algorithm, which inductively samples particles that are guaranteed to satisfy the constraint on the mean. Application of IMeDeT on synthetic and real EEG data shows that incorporating a priori constraints on the state improves the tracking accuracy as well as the convergence rate of the tracker.

doc_title: Time accounting artificial neural networks for biochemical process models
doc_abstract: © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2017.This paper is focused on developing more efficient computational schemes for modeling in biochemical processes. A theoretical framework for estimation of process kinetic rates based on different temporal (time accounting) artificial neural network (ANN) architectures is introduced. Three ANNs that explicitly consider temporal aspects of modeling are exemplified: (i) Recurrent Neural Network (RNN) with global feedback (from the network output to the network input); (ii) time-lagged feedforward neural network (TLFN), and (iii) reservoir computing network (RCN). Crystallization growth rate estimation is the benchmark for testing the methodology. The proposed hybrid (dynamical ANN and analytical submodel) schemes are promising modeling framework when the process is strongly nonlinear and particularly when input-output data is the only information available.

doc_title: Regression approach for automatic detection of attention lapses
doc_abstract: © 2016 IEEE.Certain professions rely on the ability to maintain attention constant throughout long periods of time, like truck drivers, air traffic controllers, health professionals, among others. These could greatly benefit from the development of a real-time alerting system that will call subjects back to task even before lapses occur or shortly after they happened. Attention levels have been shown to relate to the properties of the electroencephalogram (EEG). In this paper, we propose for the first time a regression approach to detect fluctuating levels of attention, based on spatiotemporal patterns extracted from EEG recordings. Previous studies have shown that reaction time is related to the level of task related attention. Moment-to-moment fluctuations in attention level are paralleled by moment-tomoment fluctuations in reaction time (faster reaction times are related to high attention allocation). We took advantage of this parallel and used reaction time data obtained during a repetitive visuomotor task as a proxy for task related attention level. Furthermore, instead of defining high attention versus low attention periods, we labeled each moment according to a continuum based on each trial's reaction time. In order to determine if it is possible to predict attention level from EEG features, we developed regression models between the extracted features and the subject's reaction time.

doc_title: Learning to decode human emotions with Echo State Networks
doc_abstract: © 2015 Elsevier Ltd.The aim of this paper is to identify the common neural signatures based on which the positive and negative valence of human emotions across multiple subjects can be reliably discriminated. The brain activity is observed via Event Related Potentials (ERPs). ERPs are transient components in the Electroencephalography (EEG) generated in response to a stimulus. ERPs were collected while subjects were viewing images with positive or negative emotional content. Building inter-subject discrimination models is a challenging problem due to the high ERPs variability between individuals. We propose to solve this problem with the aid of the Echo State Networks (ESN) as a general framework for extracting the most relevant discriminative features between multiple subjects. The original feature vector is mapped into the reservoir feature space defined by the number of the reservoir equilibrium states. The dominant features are extracted iteratively from low dimensional combinations of reservoir states. The relevance of the new feature space was validated by experiments with standard supervised and unsupervised machine learning techniques. From one side this proof of concept application enhances the usability context of the reservoir computing for high dimensional static data representations by low-dimensional feature transformation as functions of the reservoir states. From other side, the proposed solution for emotion valence detection across subjects is suitable for brain studies as a complement to statistical methods. This problem is important because such decision making systems constitute "virtual sensors" of hidden emotional states, which are useful in psychology science research and clinical applications.

The brain activity is observed via Event Related Potentials (ERPs). ERPs are transient components in the Electroencephalography (EEG) generated in response to a stimulus. ERPs were collected while subjects were viewing images with positive or negative emotional content. Building inter-subject discrimination models is a challenging problem due to the high ERPs variability between individuals. We propose to solve this problem with the aid of the Echo State Networks (ESN) as a general framework for extracting the most relevant discriminative features between multiple subjects. The original feature vector is mapped into the reservoir feature space defined by the number of the reservoir equilibrium states. The dominant features are extracted iteratively from low dimensional combinations of reservoir states. The relevance of the new feature space was validated by experiments with standard supervised and unsupervised machine learning techniques. From one side this proof of concept application enhances the usability context of the reservoir computing for high dimensional static data representations by low-dimensional feature transformation as functions of the reservoir states. From other side, the proposed solution for emotion valence detection across subjects is suitable for brain studies as a complement to statistical methods. This problem is important because such decision making systems constitute “virtual sensors” of hidden emotional states, which are useful in psychology science research and clinical applications. Keywords Echo State Networks Reservoir computing Feature selection Affective computing Event Related Potentials 1 Introduction Affective neuroscience (AN) is a new modality in the interdisciplinary research field of affective computing that attempts to discover the neural correlates between human emotions and the registered brain activity, Calvo and D’Mello (2010) and Dalgleish, Dunn, and Mobbs (2009). The Electroencephalography (EEG)-based AN has attracted more attention because it is a noninvasive, cheap and relatively easy to apply technology (AlZoubi, Calvo, & Stevens, 2009; Olofsson, Nordin, Sequeira, & Polich, 2008; Petrantonakis & Hadjileontiadis, 2010). Most of the emotion recognition systems build an individual model for every subject (intra-subject models) (Chanel, Kronegg, Grandjean, & Pun, 2006; Frantzidis et al., 2010; Li & Lu, 2009; Liu, Sourina, & Nguyen, 2010; Nie, Wang, Shi, & LuS, 2011). Building inter-subject models is a harder problem due to the high neural variability between individuals. For example in Jatupaiboon, Panngum, and Israsena (2013) a real-time classification of happy/unhappy emotions elicited by pictures and classical music is proposed. The combination of features extracted from the Power Spectral Density (PSD) of the EEG signal and the Support Vector machine (SVM) classifier resulted into 75.62% classification accuracy for the intra-subject models and significantly lower (62.12%) accuracy for the inter-subject generalization. Better results are presented in Bhowmik, Das, Konar, Nandi, and Chakraborty (2010), where the emotion clustering is based on similarities in the EEG-related phase trajectories. For simulated data with Signal to Noise Ratio (SNR) <10 dB (typical for real EEG measurements) the inter-subject discrimination accuracy achieves 84%. Lin, Wang, and Jung (2010) deals with more challenging discrimination scenario of four emotional states (joy, anger, sadness and pleasure) with the inter-subject recognition accuracy of 82%. Interesting study is published in Tomé et al. (2013), where single-trial inter-subject accuracy of 80% was obtained after feature elimination of 720 features (out of 756 initial features). The studies, where the generalization of the EEG detection of emotions across subjects is explicitly considered, have to come up with the problem of ambiguity in the appropriate feature space and its high dimensionality. Therefore, the primary motivation of this paper is to identify common neural signatures based on which the emotion valence across multiple subjects can be reliably detected. The experimental scenario is built on Event Related Potentials (ERPs). ERPs are transient components in the EEG generated in response to a stimulus (high arousal images in the present study). The discrimination problem involves high dimensional, multi-channel noisy raw data, from which the initial spatio-temporal feature space is constructed. Our goal is to define reliable mechanism for feature selection and dimensionality reduction in order to achieve robust decoding and predictions of emotional states across subjects. In our previous work (Georgieva et al., 2014), we have proposed feature dimensionality reduction by correlation-based feature selection and gain ratio feature evaluation. The intra-subject discrimination accuracy improved significantly however the inter-subject models were less affected. The experience gained suggested that a reliable multi-subject neural decoding is feasible only if the features are carefully reduced to the most discriminative features. In this paper we go further and show that the Echo State Networks (ESNs) can serve as an effective feature selection procedure that improved the discrimination of human emotion valence from ERP signals. The ESNs are dynamical structures designed to facilitate learning in Recurrent Neural Networks (RNN), normally applied for time series modeling. Using ESNs for static data classification and clustering gained less attention. However, there are examples in the literature like neural systems possessing multi-stable attractors (Brody, Romo, & Kepecs, 2003) that perform temporal integration aimed to discriminate between multiple alternatives. In other works (Ackley, Hinton, & Sejnowski, 1985; Hinton & Salakhutdinov, 2006) unsupervised learning procedures that minimize given energy function were proposed to achieve network equilibrium states that reflect given data structure. In Woodward and Ikegami (2011) it was proposed to use ESN as feature extraction stage of image classification. Their role was to “draw out” silent underlying features of the data to be used further to train a feedforward neural network classifier. In Peng, Guo, Lei, and Peng (2011) the idea to exploit equilibrium states of the ESN reservoir in order to design multiple-clusters ESN reservoirs was proposed. It was inspired by complex network topologies imitating cortical networks of the mammalian brain. In Lazar, Pipa, and Triesch (2007) it was reported that the Intrinsic Plasticity (IP) algorithm in combination with Spike-time Dependent plasticity (STDP) of synaptic weights changes the connectivity matrix of the network in such way that the recurrent connections capture the peculiarities of the input stimuli so that the network activation patterns can be separated by an unsupervised clustering technique. The idea described in the present paper was motivated initially from stability analysis of the ESN and proposed for the first time in Koprinkova-Hristova and Tontchev (2012). In this work the original multidimensional data was represented by two-dimensional (2D) projections of the reservoir steady states. The proposed (Koprinkova-Hristova & Tontchev, 2012) ESN feature selection methodology was successfully applied to solve clustering problems on a number of different data sets (Koprinkova-Hristova & Alexiev, 2013, 2014a, 2014b; Koprinkova-Hristova, Alexiev, Borisova, Jelev, & Atanassov, 2013; Koprinkova-Hristova, Angelova, Borisova, & Jelev, 2013; Koprinkova-Hristova, Doukovska, & Kostov, 2013). The Spiking Neural Network (SNN) architecture NeuCube proposed by Kasabov (2014) is an effective reservoir-based approach for spatio-temporal brain data processing (such as dynamic EEG data) and the feature extraction is inherent in the model. However, in the present study guided by experts with neurophysiological domain knowledge, static features suitable for neurological interpretation are first extracted from the EEG data, i.e. amplitudes and latency of early/late brain waves. Besides keeping the physical meaning of the original feature space, the conversion of averaged ERP signals into static feature vectors is a way to deal with huge amount of data collected from many subjects over multiple sessions and trials (big data issues). The main contribution of this paper is the robust ERP-based emotion valence recognition system validated for high dimensional data of 26 subjects. In order to reduce the high variability of neural osculation between subjects, we propose to use the Echo State Network (ESN) as a general framework for extracting the most discriminative, less subject specific features. The novelty of the IP tuned reservoir consists in creating low dimensional projections (2D, 3D, etc.) from all ESN features (reservoir neurons equilibrium states) and find the optimal projections that maximize the recognition accuracy. The intuition behind is to consider these projections as “views” from different angles to the multidimensional feature space, i.e. in this way we “rotate” and “explore” the feature space from different “viewpoints”. The proposed approach was validated by experiments with standard supervised and unsupervised machine learning techniques. This solution is important because such decision making systems constitute “virtual sensors” of hidden emotional states, which are useful in psychology science research and clinical applications. The paper is organized as follows. In Section 2 our novel Intrinsic Plasticity (IP)-based algorithm for feature extraction from the ESN reservoir equilibrium states is presented. In Section 3 we describe the ERP data set. In Section 4 the relevance of the ESN-extracted features for subject independent emotion valance discrimination is validated by experiments with standard clustering and classification techniques. Discussion of the results and conclusions are summarized in Section 5. 2 ESN reservoir training with intrinsic plasticity 2.1 Echo state networks Echo State Networks (ESN) represent a class of recurrent neural networks (RNN) where the RNN (called reservoir) is generated randomly and remains unchanged during network training (Lukosevicius & Jaeger, 2009). Only the RNN output (the readout) is trained. This new approach to RNN design and training was proposed independently by Wolfgang Maass under the name Liquid State Machines (Maass, Natschlaeger, & Markram, 2002) and by Herbert Yaeger under the name of Echo State Networks (Jaeger, 2001) and is nowadays collectively referred to as Reservoir Computing (RC). Major advances in the overall field have been published in Schrauwen, Wandermann, Verstraeten, Steil, and Stroobandt (2008). The basic structure of an ESN, presented in Fig. 1 , consists of a reservoir of randomly connected dynamic neurons with sigmoid nonlinearities f res (usually hyperbolic tangent): (1) r ( k ) = f res ( W in i n ( k ) + W res r ( k − 1 ) ) and a linear readout f out (usually identity function) at the output: (2) out ( k ) = f out ( W out [ in ( k ) r ( k ) ] ) . Here k denotes discrete time instant; in ( k ) is a vector of network inputs, r ( k ) —a vector of the reservoir neurons states and out ( k ) —a vector of network outputs; n in , n out and n r are the dimensions of the corresponding vectors in, out and r respectively; W out is a trainable n out × ( n in + n r ) matrix; W in and W res are n r × n in and n r × n r matrices that are randomly generated and are not trainable. In some applications direct connection from the input to the readout is omitted. The main advantage of the ESN is the simplified training algorithm since only weights of the connections from the reservoir to the readout neurons are subject to training. Thus instead of the backpropagation-through-time learning much faster least squares method can be used. The key idea is that having rich enough reservoirs of nonlinearities will allow to approximate quite complex nonlinear dependence between input and output vectors by tuning only the linear readout weights (Jaeger, 2001). Although the reservoir connections and their weights are randomly generated, in order to prevent improper behavior of ESN, the reservoir needs to possess the so called “echo state property” as formulated in Jaeger (2001). The basic rule formulation is: the effect of input disturbances should vanish gradually in time that means the dynamic reservoir must be stable. According to this rule, a reservoir weight matrix with spectral radius below one needs to be generated. However as pointed out in Lukosevicius and Jaeger (2009) this condition will not guaranty ESN stable behavior in general. Therefore, many task-dependent recipes for improvement of reservoir connections were proposed, see Verstraeten, Schrauwen, D’Haene, and Stroobandt (2007) for a brief review. 2.2 Intrinsic plasticity Since one of the laws of thermodynamics says that any stable stationary state has a local maximum of entropy (Haddad, Chellaboina, & Nersesov, 2005), it can be expected that maximization of entropy at the ESN reservoir output could increase its stability. This motivated several works proposing ESN reservoir improvement by its entropy maximization (Ozturk, Xu, & Principe, 2007). Other authors proposed the biologically motivated adaptation rule called Intrinsic Plasticity (IP) based on mechanisms of changing neural excitability in response to the distribution of the input stimuli (Schrauwen et al., 2008; Steil, 2007). In Koprinkova-Hristova and Palm (2011) we have shown that in fact IP training achieves balance between maximization of entropy at the ESN reservoir output and its concentration around the pre-specified mean value increasing at the same time reservoir stability. IP adaptation rule aims at maximization of information transmission through the ESN that is equivalent to its output entropy maximization. A gradient method for adjusting the biases and an additional gain term was implemented. The goal is to achieve the desired distribution of the outputs by minimizing the Kullback–Leibler divergence: (3) D K L ( p ( r ) , p d ( r ) ) = ∫ p ( r ) log ( p ( r ) p d ( r ) ) d r . That is a measure of the difference between the actual p ( r ) and the desired p d ( r ) probability distribution of reservoir outputs r . Since the commonly used transfer function of neurons is the hyperbolic tangent, the proper target distribution that maximizes the information at the output according to Schrauwen et al. (2008) is the Gaussian distribution with variance σ and mean μ : (4) p d ( r ) = 1 σ 2 π exp ( − ( r − μ ) 2 2 σ 2 ) . Hence Eq. (3) can be rearranged as follows: (5) D K L ( p ( r ) , p d ( r ) ) = − H ( r ) + 1 2 σ 2 E ( ( r − μ ) 2 ) + log 1 σ 2 π , where H denotes entropy. The last term in (5) is constant and the second term determines the deviation of the reservoir output r from the desired mean value. The minimization of (5) is a compromise between the entropy maximization and the minimization of the distance between μ and r . In order to achieve this effect two additional reservoir parameters–the gain a and the bias b (both vectors with size n r )–are introduced as follows: (6) r ( k ) = f res ( diag ( a ) W in in ( k ) + diag ( a ) W res r ( k − 1 ) + b ) . The IP training is a procedure that adjusts vectors a and b using iterative gradient descent as follows: a it = a it − 1 + Δ a b it = b it − 1 + Δ b where it denotes iteration number and the gradients Δ a and Δ b are derivatives of Kullback–Leibler divergence with respect to vectors a and b . In the case of hyperbolic tangent reservoir neurons ( f res = tanh ) the gradients are: Δ b = − η ( − μ σ 2 + r σ 2 ( 2 σ 2 + 1 − r 2 + μ r ) ) Δ a = η a + Δ bnet input net input = W in in + W res r . Here η is the learning rate. The IP procedure tends to concentrate the reservoir outputs according to the parameters of the targeted Gaussian distribution p d ( r ) in the interval [ − 3 σ , + 3 σ ] around a desired mean value μ . The equilibrium state of the reservoir r e for a constant input in c can be determined as: (7) r e = tanh ( diag ( a ) W in in c + diag ( a ) W res r e + b ) . In case b = 0 and in c = 0 , the equilibrium will be at the origin of the reservoir state space coordinate system. Otherwise it will be moved depending on the values of input in c and bias b vectors. Since the input weight matrix remains constant, the first term in the brackets will be also constant for a constant inputs in c . Thus we can consider it together with the bias term as a common bias for a given input vector: (8) r e = tanh ( diag ( a ) W res r e + b in c ) , b in c = diag ( a ) W in in c + b . The reservoir equilibrium states vary randomly within the hyperbolic tangent interval [ − 1 + 1 ] . After the IP adaptation rule they will be squeezed into the interval determined by the variance σ . The convergence of the reservoir states to the expected distributions is proven in Schrauwen et al. (2008). Typical values for the key parameters of the algorithm were chosen: zero mean ( μ = 0 ), variance σ = 0.1 , learning rate η = 0.0005 and a = 1 and b = 0 as initial values of the tinning parameters suggested by Schrauwen et al. (2008). The IP training stops when no significant changes of the equilibrium states are observed. This happens usually after 5–10 iterations. Similar conclusions were achieved in our previous experiments (Koprinkova-Hristova & Palm, 2011). The IP procedure is a non-supervised tuning algorithm that does not aim to fit network output to some target data but rather aims to fit the reservoir connections to reflect input data structure, therefore overfitting issues are not relevant. 2.3 ESN reservoir for extraction of low dimensional features During the investigations in Koprinkova-Hristova and Palm (2011) we have observed that the reservoir equilibrium states are concentrated in several regions and they depend on the input vectors. If the input vectors are close in the input space, they will result in close equilibrium points in the reservoir state. Then a question arose: is it possible to use this effect for discrimination purposes? This question formulated the main idea of the present work to consider the equilibrium reservoir states after IP training as the new feature space and extract the features with the highest discrimination capacity. The algorithm for extraction of these low dimensional feature vectors is the following: Step 1: Randomly generate the initial ESN reservoir. The topology of the ESN is defined by the input (the original) feature space. The size of the ESN input vector is equal to the number of the original features. Since we explore only the reservoir output, the size of the readout can be any positive integer value and therefore it can be set to one. Step 2: IP adaptation of the ESN reservoir states. IP adaptation rule according to (Eqs. (4)–(8)) is applied iteratively to the feature vectors of all training examples of the data set. Step 3: Calculate the equilibrium states of the reservoir neurons. Since it is hard to solve analytically the equations for the equilibrium states corresponding to each input vector in c : (9) r e = tanh ( diag ( a ) W in in c + diag ( a ) W res r e + b ) the equilibrium states r e are iteratively computed until reaching the steady state. Step 4 Generate low dimensional projections of the equilibrium states (combinations of two, three or more reservoir neurons). This is an iterative procedure consisting of the following sub-steps: (a) Create all possible two dimensional (2D) combinations of the equilibrium states of the reservoir neurons, obtained after IP training. Use these 2D combinations as features to fit classification or clustering models (e.g. k-means, FCM, etc.); rank the models based on their accuracy. (b) Select C best ranked models. Use their corresponding 2D feature vectors and generate three dimensional (3D) combinations adding one by one the rest of reservoir neurons equilibrium states. Use these 3D combinations to fit the models and rank them. (c) Select again C best ranked combinations and as in the previous step use them to create four-dimensional (4D) feature vectors; fit and rank the models. (d) Repeat the same procedure generating higher dimensional feature vectors until no significant improvement in the discrimination accuracy of the classifiers is observed. The algorithm described above is outlined in Table 1 . In the implementation of the experiments C is equal to 20. Step 4 is computationally the most expensive step. Overall, the computational complexity for building the discriminative model with each combination of neurons is factorial O ( n r − ! / ( n r − k + 1 ) ! ∗ k ! ) , where n r is the reservoir size and k is the number of neurons in the combination. In order to control the computational load in the above algorithm, only 2D projections (Step 4a) are a complete set of n r ∗ ( n r − 1 ) / 2 combinations. Choosing the C best ranked 2D projections from the previous iteration for the 3D (Step 4b) and 4D (Step 4c) subsequent steps reduces the computational complexity to linear O ( ( n r ) ) for these stages. 3 Data set description We consider learning to discriminate emotional states of human subjects, based on their brain activity observed via Event Related Potentials (ERPs). Emotional behavior is organized along two psycho-physiologic dimensions: (i) valence, varying from negative to positive, and (ii) arousal, varying from low to high. The combination of these two affective dimensions forms four emotional categories, which incorporate several discrete human emotions, such as joy, pleasure, excitement, melancholy, anger, fear, disgust, etc. It is also assumed that valence and arousal are orthogonal, independent dimensions of emotional stimulus. Thus, any emotion-related biosignal is differentiated according to its valence or arousal dimension. In the present work, the ERPs signals were recorded while 26 female volunteers were viewing pictures selected from the International Affective Picture System (IAPS) repository. A total of 24 high arousal (IAPS rating > 6) images with positive valence ( M = 7.29 ± 0.65 ) and negative valence ( M = 1.47 ± 0.24 ) were selected. For each image, signals from 21 EEG channels were sampled at 1 kHz and stored (see Table 2 ). Each image was presented 3 times in a pseudo-random order and each trial lasted 3500 ms: during the first 750 ms, a fixation cross was presented, then one of the images was presented during 500 ms and at last a black screen appeared during 2250 ms. The raw EEG signals were first filtered (band-pass filter between 0.1 and 30 Hz.), eye-movement corrected, baseline compensated and segmented into epochs using NeuroScan software. The single-trial signal length is 950 ms with 150 ms before the stimulus onset. The ensemble average for each condition (positive/negative valence) was also computed and filtered using a Butterworth filter of 4th order with passband [0.5–15] Hz. Thus, the filtered ensemble average signals cover the frequency band ranges corresponding to Delta ([0.5–4] Hz), Theta ([4–8] Hz) and Alpha neural activity ([8–12] Hz) (Bozhkov, Georgieva, & Trifonov, 2014). Most of the ERP-based affective state detection systems rely on the frequency content of the signals (Jatupaiboon et al., 2013). The features are measures of the ERP energy in certain frequency bands, as for example Power Spectral Density (PSD) or Spectral Power Asymmetry (SPA). However, recent studies report evidence about temporal correlates between emotional stimuli processing and the occurrence of subsequent positive and negative potentials (waves C1, P1, P2, P3) when the stimulus is loaded with intensive emotions (Pourtois, Grandjean, Sander, & Vuilleumier, 2004; Santos, Iglesias, Olivares, & Young, 2008; Stolarova, Keil, & Moratti, 2006). These waves are associated with specific time of occurrence (early/late waves). Therefore, in the present study, temporal features (amplitudes and latencies) are extracted from the filtered, segmented and ensemble averaged ERP data. Starting by the localization of the first minimum after time t = 0 s , the features are defined as a sequence of the local positive and negative picks, and their respective latencies (time of occurrence). Twelve temporal features are stored (Table 3 ) corresponding to the amplitudes of the first three local minimums ( A min 1 , A min 2 , A min 3 ), the first three local maximums ( A max 1 , A max 2 , A max 3 ), and their associated latencies ( L min 1 , L min 2 , L min 3 , L max 1 , L max 2 , L max 3 ). As a result, the initial feature set is a matrix X with dimension of 252 columns (21 channels x12 features) and 52 lines (the ensemble averaged positive and negative labeled trials of 26 subjects). The three-step algorithm proposed in Section 2 (Table 1) for ESN-based feature selection is applied on the normalized feature matrix (10) X ̄ = X − mean ( X ) std ( X ) . 4 Emotion valence discrimination—experimental results In this section we use the ESN extracted features to discriminate the positive and negative emotion valence across multiple subjects. In order to eliminate the problem of choosing the “wrong” or the “lucky” learning model we tested various standard learning techniques: k-means and fuzzy C-means clustering (unsupervised methods) and five classifiers (Linear Discriminant Analysis, k-Nearest Neighbor, Naïve Bayes, Support Vector Machines, Decision Tree) as supervised methods. The size of the ESN input vector corresponds to the number of the original features (in this case 252 features). The size of the reservoir varies between 10 and 500 neurons. The results with 10, 30, 50, 100, 150, 300 and 500 neurons are visualized on the next figures and tables. 4.1 Clustering approach We compare the discrimination capacity of k-means and fuzzy C-means (FCM) clustering algorithms for varying reservoir dimension provided with the following feature sets: (i) All equilibrium states of the reservoir (ESN all); (ii) Two dimensional combinations of equilibrium states. In Fig. 2 are presented only the results with the 2D feature sets that maximize the accuracy of each clustering method (ESN 2D); (iii) The original feature matrix X from Eq. (7) (orig). The results are summarized in Fig. 2. The achieved accuracy values (%) are given in Table 4 . Clustering based on the best 2D combinations of equilibrium states (ESN 2D) outperform by far the clustering using all reservoir equilibrium states (ESN all) or direct clustering of the original feature matrix Eq. (7) (orig). Note that the clustering based on ESN all is worse (particularly when the reservoir size increases) compared to the direct clustering with orig. Thus, the original features X and the set of all equilibrium states (for large variation of the reservoir dimension from 10 to 500 neurons) do not provide better discrimination than a random chance and therefore are not appropriate for inter-subject discrimination models. In contrast, 2D features extracted particularly from reservoirs with high number of neurons (150, 300, 500) achieve close to 80% accuracy which is very promising result in the context of this challenging application. 4.2 Classification approach Now we apply Linear Discriminant Analysis (LDA), k-Nearest Neighbors (kNN), Naïve Bayes (NB), Support Vector Machines (SVM) and Decision Trees (DT), to discriminate the emotion valence for the following feature set scenarios: (i) All equilibrium states of the reservoir (Fig. 3 ); (ii) Two dimensional combinations of equilibrium states (the first iteration of step 4 of the algorithm presented in Section 2.3). In Fig. 4 are presented only the results with the 2D feature sets that maximize the classification accuracy of each classifier; (iii) Three dimensional combinations of equilibrium states (the second iteration of step 4 of the algorithm in Section 2.3). The combinations are obtained from the best twenty 2D combinations of reservoir states kept at the first iteration. In Fig. 5 are presented the results with the best 3D feature vectors of each classifier; (iv) Four dimensional combinations of equilibrium states (the third iteration of step 4 of the algorithm in Section 2.3). The combinations are obtained from the best 3D combinations of reservoir states kept at the second iteration. In Fig. 6 are presented the results with the best 4D feature vectors. At each training iteration, data belonging to one subject (26 subjects in total) is left aside and used for model testing (leave-one-subject-out cross validation). Thus, 26-fold cross validation is performed and only testing results are presented in the paper. The general observation in all scenarios is that increasing the reservoir dimension improves the classification accuracy. This tendency is related with the increasing number of combinations and therefore higher search resolution for discovering the best discriminative feature vectors. Note however, that scenario (i) seems not affected by the variation in the reservoir size. The accuracy values (%) associated with Figs. 3–6 are given in Tables 5–8 , respectively. Another interesting observation is that overall the classification techniques outperform the clustering methods, particularly when all equilibrium states are considered as features. The auto-encoder training in deep neural networks (DNN) and the subsequent hidden layer extraction have a similar interpretation as the system of ESN ( 2 D ⇒ 3 D ⇒ 4 D feature combinations) and a classifier proposed here. We made experiments with DNN varying the hidden layer (HL) dimensions: HL1 (100-30), HL2 (50-20), HL3 (40-1). The best results were obtained for DNN topology of (20-5-1), with only 60% of achieved testing accuracy. The confusion matrix is TP = 15 ; TN = 16 ; FP = 11 ; FN = 10 . Both classes are equally misclassified. 5 Conclusions In this paper an inter-subject valence recognition system is proposed, where the Echo State Networks (ESN) are introduced as a mechanism for selecting the most relevant discriminative features between multiple subjects. The low dimensional feature vectors are extracted from the equilibrium states of the ESN reservoir, obtained after Intrinsic Plasticity (IP) adaptation. The algorithm proposed generates iteratively low dimensional combinations of the reservoir equilibrium states, starting from 2D combinations and subsequent higher order combinations build upon the best performing lower order feature vectors. The relevance of the ESN extracted feature vectors was validated by experiments with typical clustering and classification techniques. 80% of correct clustering of the positive and negative emotion valence across multiple subjects obtained with feature vectors having the surprising low dimension of 2 elements is a very promising result in the context of this challenging application. Moreover, 95% correct classification obtained with 4D feature vectors outperform all previously published results of affective computing based on brain neural data (ERPs). The price to pay for this significant discrimination improvement is the computational time required to test all feature vector combinations and extract the most discriminative ones. This problem is particularly relevant for big reservoirs. For example for a reservoir with 500 neurons, 124750 combinations of 2D equilibrium states need to be analyzed. If higher order combinations (3D, 4D) or more neurons are required this number increases exponentially. Therefore, in the algorithm we proposed in Section 2.3, this problem is controlled by the iterative way of generating higher order combinations as a function of only a small portion of neurons that gained this privilege at the previous iteration (the C best ranked low-dimensional combinations at the previous step). The choice of C = 20 reflects computational power restrictions. There is a certain analogy between the dimensionality reduction approach we propose here and the genetic optimization where the initial population can be seen as the complete set of reservoir equilibrium states. At each iteration we make new equilibrium states combinations using the best combination(s) at the previous iteration, which is very much the same with the renovation of the genetic population. We believe that from one side this work enhances the usability context of the ESN for high dimensional static data representations by low dimensional feature transformation as functions of the reservoir states. From other side, learning to decode human emotions from ERPs is an important problem because such decision making systems constitute “virtual sensors” of hidden emotional states, which are useful in psychology science research and medical applications. doc_title: A Beamformer-Particle Filter Framework for Localization of Correlated EEG Sources
doc_abstract: © 2013 IEEE.Electroencephalography (EEG)-based brain computer interface (BCI) is the most studied noninvasive interface to build a direct communication pathway between the brain and an external device. However, correlated noises in EEG measurements still constitute a significant challenge. Alternatively, building BCIs based on filtered brain activity source signals instead of using their surface projections, obtained from the noisy EEG signals, is a promising and not well-explored direction. In this context, finding the locations and waveforms of inner brain sources represents a crucial task for advancing source-based noninvasive BCI technologies. In this paper, we propose a novel multicore beamformer particle filter (multicore BPF) to estimate the EEG brain source spatial locations and their corresponding waveforms. In contrast to conventional (single-core) beamforming spatial filters, the developed multicore BPF considers explicitly temporal correlation among the estimated brain sources by suppressing activation from regions with interfering coherent sources. The hybrid multicore BPF brings together the advantages of both deterministic and Bayesian inverse problem algorithms in order to improve the estimation accuracy. It solves the brain activity localization problem without prior information about approximate areas of source locations. Moreover, the multicore BPF reduces the dimensionality of the problem to half compared with the PF solution, thus alleviating the curse of dimensionality problem. The results, based on generated and real EEG data, show that the proposed framework recovers correctly the dominant sources of brain activity.

doc_title: EEG dynamic source localization using Marginalized Particle Filtering
doc_abstract: © 2015 IEEE.Localization of the brain neural generators that create Electroencephalographs (EEGs) has been an important problem in clinical, research and technological applications related to the brain. The active regions in the brain are modeled as equivalent current dipoles, and the positions and moments of these dipoles or brain sources are estimated. So far, the brain dipoles are assumed to be fixed or time-invariant. However, recent neurological studies are showing that brain sources are not static but vary (in terms of location and moment) depending on various internal and external stimuli. This paper presents a shift in the current paradigm of brain source localization by considering dynamic sources in the brain. We formulate the brain source estimation problem from EEG measurements as a (nonlinear) state-space model. We use the Particle Filter (PF), essentially a sequential Monte Carlo method, to track the trajectory of the moving dipoles in the brain. We further address the "curse of dimensionality," issue of the PF by taking advantage of the structure of the EEG state-space model, and marginalizing out the linearly evolving states. A Kalman Filter is used to optimally estimate the linear elements, whereas the PF is used to track only the non-linear components. This technique reduces the dimension of the problem; thus exponentially reducing the computational cost. Our simulation results show that, where the PF fails, the Marginalized PF is able to successfully track two dipoles in the brain with only 500 particles.

doc_title: Comparison of consumer purchase intention between interactive and augmented reality shopping platforms through statistical analyses
doc_abstract: © 2015 IEEE.The objective of this study is to explore the effectiveness of three digital shopping platforms (Plain Interactive, Marker-based Augmented Reality and Markerless Augmented Reality), on the impressions and purchase intentions of consumers. The study is mainly interested in analysing whether intelligent shopping platforms with AR elements provide any added advantage to an advertised product in the form of favourable attitude or a stronger purchase impulse. During the tests with the three shopping platforms, quantitative data was collected via computerised questionnaire. High and Low class users were statistically extracted, corresponding to the high or low probability to buy or recommend the advertised brand. The results show that Markerless AR system clearly outperforms the Marker-based AR and the Plain Interactive in terms of positive attitude from the users. The second better performing system is the Marker-based AR, which closely follows the Markerless AR, while the Plain Interactive system obtains least approval.

doc_title: Learning to decode human emotions from event-related potentials
doc_abstract: © 2014, The Natural Computing Applications Forum.Reported works on electroencephalogram (EEG)-based emotion recognition systems generally employ the principles of supervised learning to build subject-dependent (single/intra-subject) models. Building subject-independent (multiple/inter-subject) models is a harder problem due to the EEG data variability between subjects. The contribution of this paper is twofold. First, we provide a framework for selection of a small number of basic temporal features, event-related potential (ERP) amplitudes, and latencies that are sufficiently robust to discriminate emotion states across multiple subjects. Second, we test comparatively the feasibility of six standard unsupervised (clustering) techniques to build intra-subject and inter-subject models to discriminate emotion valence in the ERPs collected while subjects were viewing high arousal images with positive or negative emotional content.

doc_title: Echo state networks for feature selection in affective computing
doc_abstract: © 2015 Springer International Publishing Switzerland.The Echo State Networks (ESNs) are dynamical structures designed initially to facilitate learning in Recurrent Neural Networks which are normally applied for time series modeling. In this paper we show that the ESN reservoirs can serve as an effective feature selection procedure that improved the discrimination of human emotion valence from EEG signals, a task that belongs to the research field of affective computing. A number of supervised and unsupervised machine learning techniques provided with the new feature vector extracted from ESN reservoir states were comparatively studied with respect to their discrimination accuracy. This novel application serves as a proof of concept for the possibility of extending the usability of the ESNs in classification or clustering frameworks.

doc_title: Novel approach for simultaneous sediment classification and concentration determination of water turbidity
doc_abstract: © 2015 SPIE.A new approach for data analysis and classification for datasets obtained by a multiparameter optical turbidity sensor is proposed. This approach is based on the combination of statistical or machine learning methods such as linear regressions and clustering analysis. A case study is presented using a 6 dimensional fiber optic sensor to simultaneously classify types of sediments and concentration. Results show a 79% of success for the used training data sets. The methodology proposed is flexible because can be easily adapted to other physical scenarios.

doc_title: EEG-based subject independent affective computing models
doc_abstract: © The Authors. Published by Elsevier B.V.Electroencephalography (EEG) based affective computing is a new research field that aims to find neural correlates between human emotions and the registered EEG signals. Typically, emotion recognition systems are personalized, i.e. the discrimination models are subject-dependent. Building subject-independent models is a harder problem due to the high EEG variability between individuals. In this paper we propose a unified system for efficient discrimination of positive and negative emotions in a group of 26 users. The users were exposed to high arousal affective images and the recorded brain signals differentiated according to their positive and negative valence. Major challenge in building subject independent affective models is to identify the most discriminative features between subjects. The focus of the present study is to find a relevant feature selection approach that extracts features suitable for neurophysiological interpretation and validation. Spatial (channels) and temporal (brain waves peaks and their respective latencies) features are extracted from the EEG signals. The feature selection strategies explored (Independent spatial and temporal feature selection, Sequential Feature Selection, Feature Elimination based on data descriptive statistics) are consistent in selecting parietal and occipital channels and late waves (P200, P300) as better encoder of the emotion valence state and less variable across subjects. These results are in line with neurophysiological hypothesis of visually elicited human emotions - brain activity correlation. The relevance of the selected features was validated by five standard and one majority vote classifiers.

Typically, emo- tion recognition systems are personalized, i.e. the discrimination models are subject-dependent. Building subject-independent models is a harder problem due to the high EEG variability be- tween individuals. In this paper we propose a unified system for efficient discrimination of positive and negative emotions in a group of 26 users. The users were exposed to high arousal affective images and the recorded brain signals differentiated according to their positive and negative valence. Major challenge in building subject independent affective models is to iden- tify the most discriminative features between subjects. The focus of the present study is to find a relevant feature selection approach that extracts features suitable for neurophysiological interpretation and validation. Spatial (channels) and temporal (brain waves peaks and their respective latencies) features are extracted from the EEG signals. The feature selection strate- gies explored (Independent spatial and temporal feature selection, Sequential Feature Selection, Feature Elimination based on data descriptive statistics) are consistent in selecting parietal and occipital channels and late waves (P200, P300) as better encoder of the emotion valence state and less variable across subjects. These results are in line with neurophysiological hypothesis of visually elicited human emotions - brain activity correlation. The relevance of the selected features was validated by five standard and one majority vote classifiers. Keywords: subject independent affective computing, emotion valence recognition, Event Related Po- tentials (ERPs), feature selection 1 Introduction Affective neuroscience (AN) is an interdisciplinary research field that attempts to find neural correlates between human emotions and the registered brain activity, [2], [3].
